text.p: These are the leading stories in the Zimbabwe press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- The cabinet has decided to disband the state-run Central Purchasing Authority, which has been hit by a rash of scandals involving the misappropriation and disappearance of up to Z$100 million in public funds so far this year.

- The government's privatisation drive is gathering momentum and two state-owned companies -- the Commercial Bank of Zimbabwe and the Cotton Company of Zimbabwe -- are planning share offers to raise a total of Z$1 billion in the local market.

- All commercial attaches at Zimbabwe's foreign missions have been recalled as the government, struggling to inject new life into the economy, intensifies its campaign for foreign investment, sources said.
- A consortium of local businessmen and Russian partners have set up a cargo airline whose first aircraft flew into the country last week.

- An official from the Finance Ministry says the government neglected to amend the Customs and Excise Act to allow for duty- free importation of capital goods, a lapse which is compromising the implementation of projects in export processing zones.
- Organisation of African Unity Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim arrived in Harare on Wednesday for talks with current OAU chairman Robert Mugabe.
- Zimbabwe's parliament on Wednesday ratified a Z$957 million loan agreement signed by the government with international agencies to finance the construction of a new terminal for Harare Airport.
